meanings.def: willing to do things that are difficult, dangerous or painful; not afraid
examples: brave men and women
Be brave!
I wasn't brave enough to tell her what I thought of her.
Desperation had made me brave.
She has been incredibly brave.
He was as brave as a lion on the rugby field.
Can't some brave soul save her from this fate?
She took the brave decision to start her own business.
She died after a brave fight against cancer.
He felt homesick, but made a brave attempt to appear cheerful.
a vision of a brave new Britain

meanings.def: a situation or society that changes in a way that is meant to improve people’s lives but is often a source of extra problems
examples: the brave new world of technology
the architects' vision of a brave new world of pristine concrete

meanings.def: to pretend that you feel confident and happy when you do not
examples: I had to put on a brave face and try to show him that I wasn’t worried.
She put a brave face on her illness.

idioms.def: a situation or society that changes in a way that is meant to improve people’s lives but is often a source of extra problems
examples: the brave new world of technology
the architects' vision of a brave new world of pristine concrete

idioms.idiom: put on a brave face | put a brave face on something
idioms.def: to pretend that you feel confident and happy when you do not
examples: I had to put on a brave face and try to show him that I wasn’t worried.
She put a brave face on her illness.

meanings.def: to have to deal with somebody/something difficult or unpleasant in order to achieve something
examples: He did not feel up to braving the journalists at the airport.
Over a thousand people braved the elements (= went outside in spite of the bad weather) to attend the march.
The firemen braved the flames to rescue the family.
America, the land of the free and the home of the brave
